Supplies : - 2 one-gallon containers to store the detergent in -LRB- I recycled an old vinegar jug + laundry soap jug -RRB- - A measuring cup - A two gallon bucket to make it in -LRB- I used a mop bucket -RRB- - Funnel -LRB- made things a lot easier -RRB- - 1 medium-size potIngredients : - 3/4 cup Dr. Bronner 's Castile Soap -LRB- any kind - I used the Baby Mild/Unscented kind -RRB- - 1/2 cup Super Washing Soda - 1/2 cup Baking Soda or 20 Mule Borax -LRB- I used Baking Soda -RRB- - Essential oil -LRB- optional -RRB- How to make : - Fill 2 cups of water into medium pot and boil - Put boiling water into bucket - Add baking soda  stir constantly - Add Super Washing Soda  stir constantly -LRB- it may turn into a watery paste - that 's OK -RRB- - Fill two gallon bucket up almost all the way with warm tap water - Add Dr. Bronner 's soap  stir constantly for two minutes to get it all incorporated - Add essential oils if you 'd like - 20-50 drops or whatever -LRB- I used 15 drops of peppermint for just a faint smell  but I ca n't really smell it - may use a tiny but more next time -RRB- The consistency is going to be very watery and you 're going to think \ `` this is n't right .

* The Knife : It 's a reasonably sharp and thin blade and of course it 's cheap versus a dedicated knife ... but it comes handy in a pinch.I usually never forget my personal carry knife so this little blade gets seldom use but after years of owning my first SD it finally needed a light sharpening ... two or three passes on a stone and it was sharp again ... got ta love soft steel.So that wraps it up on the tools with only one word of advice : use rubbing alcohol and wipe down the tools you use for sanitary reasons then wipe off the alcohol and dry.The tools are polished stainless and fight off rust quite well but wipe the alcohol completely from the tools ... if it sits on the steel for extended periods of time it will eat into the finish.The Handles : Plastics can do two things for a consumer-they can win someone over and prove their worth or they can break and dissapoint someone ... Victorinox just uses a basic plastic and nothing specialized like delrin or zytel for the handle scales.But I 've tossed my keys on the kitchen table countless times and I 've dropped my keys on concrete a good share of times and both my old SD and my new one have never cracked or shattered  only scratches.The handle colors have changed over the years  first time I bought one they were only available in Red or Black and the colors seem to vary throughout the years ... my new one was in Forest Green -LRB- seems discontinued in that color -RRB- .
